Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = u(t) + iv(t) \\) governed by the system of differential equations \\(\\dot{u} = Au\\) and \\(\\dot{v} = Bv\\), where both A and B are constant matrices. To study the behavior of the system, an integral transformation \\( h(z) = \\int e^{-st}z(t) dt \\) is applied, with s being a complex parameter.

If \\( z(t) \\) is transformed by \\( h(z) \\) and then allowed to evolve according to the original system without further intervention, will the transformed state \\( h(z)(T) \\) at time T be the same as if \\( z(t) \\) was directly evolved to T without transformation?
Explanation: The transformation \\( h(z) \\) essentially changes the representation from time domain to complex frequency domain, altering how the dynamics are observed and analyzed. As this transformation is a form of integration, it aggregates the history of the system up to time T, which cannot be inverted to yield the same state as direct evolution without such a transformation.
